description._content:
Lower Condercum House can be seen in the background with Condercum Road the first street to the right of the colliery. The pit employed over 400 people in 1934 but closed in 1939.

Reference number: TWAS: DS.CAR.17.3 

(Copyright) We're happy for you to share this digital image within the spirit of The Commons. Please cite 'Tyne & Wear Archives & Museums' when reusing. Certain restrictions on high quality reproductions and commercial use of the original physical version apply though; if you're unsure please email archives@twmuseums.org.uk.

To purchase a hi-res copy please email archives@twmuseums.org.uk quoting the title and reference number.

note._content: This was known as "the Cottage" Colliery Yard. Lived here from 1947 to 1954. The house was used as an ARP command post in World War 2
note.author: 46034804@N07

note._content: This was the Jes-Dene "pop" factory in 1950
note.author: 46034804@N07

note._content: These were the stables for the pit ponies.
note.author: 46034804@N07

note._content: These reservoirs were used as a trining ground for the ARP and later the Civil Defence post 1947
note.author: 46034804@N07

note._content: This structure was a boiler house. The boiler was very large and remained long after the building disappeared. The boiler was large enough to be used as an air raid shelter
note.author: 46034804@N07

note._content: Is this possibly the Mine owner's House?
note.author: 47817047@N07

note._content: I'm pretty sure that these trees at the end of Conhope Lane are masking Oakfield Lodge, built around 1817, which once served as a kind of coachhouse for a bigger house just a little west.  My great Aunt Sally Burnett owned the cottage from the 50's to the 70's.  Sally's dad, my great grandad Matt Burnett, worked in Charlie pit and he died in the back bedroom of this cottage.  I remember his Airedales. My grandparents Jim and Elsie Burnett later lived here.
note.author: 48622712@N06
